Background: The study was carried out to explore the epidemiologic profile of the incidence of primary brain tumors (PBTs) in Syria. Methods: A prospective and observational study was conducted in all neurosurgical departments of primary referral hospitals across Syria’s 14 districts during 2009 th Results: A total of 2,994 cases (1,532 males and 1,462 females) were identified. The average annual incidence rate of PBTs was 7.48/100,000 person-years, with gliomas (3.36), meningiomas (1.43), and sellar region tumors (1.25) being the most common. Meningiomas showed a female predominance (female: male = 1.6:1), while gliomas were more common in males (male: female = 1.3:1). The median age at the diagnosis was 52 years overall, 56 years for neuroepithelial tumors, and 48 years for meningiomas. Conclusion: The epidemiology of brain tumors in Syria shows a relatively low incidence, with differences in age and tumor distribution by sex. These findings establish a critical pre-conflict baseline for Syria and highlight potential under the diagnosis despite a functioning health infrastructure. The main object is an epidemiological goal. This represents the first attempt of estimating incidence rates of PBTs in Syria, as well as documenting PBT distribution according to age, sex, histological types, and geographical location. This study was completed based on the data of national wide registry represented all central hospitals with neurosurgical departments in 14 districts in Syria and thus we believe that we have covered almost all newly diagnosed brain tumors during the years (2009–2010). MATERIALS AND METHODS In this prospective, medical record-based, and observational study collected data between January 2009 and December 2010 from all 14 Syrian governorates. Patients aged 18 years and older diagnosed with a PBT were included. Diagnoses were made by either histopathological confirmation (in 90.45% of cases) or characteristic imaging features (9.55%). A centralized tumor registry in Damascus coordinated data collection and quality control. Age-adjusted incidence rates were calculated using direct standardization to the 2004 Syrian national census. The WHO 2021 CNS tumor classification system was used to categorize the tumors. A flowchart [ Figure 1 Figure 1: Patient selection flowchart. In collaboration with ministry of high education, ministry of health, and WHO-regional office for the Eastern Mediterranean, we have established a Brain Tumor-Registration-Center in the university hospitals in Damascus, which collect monthly information from all neurosurgical departments, in which brain tumors were diagnosed and operated in14 districts in Syria. Briefly, cases were collected according to a standardized protocol, quality control, and statistical analysis was carried out centrally using a uniform methodology, we used the direct method to estimate incidence per 100,000 person/years. The population statistics regarding number of populations, age and sex in each district were taken from the population statistics in Syria 2004 and the following updating. We are confident that we have covered almost all newly diagnosed cases of brain tumors in the country and thus we were able to calculate the incidence per 2004 population and the following updating. Patient data were analyzed, and descriptive epidemiological records were created for the patients by age, incidence rate, sex, anatomical location, geographic distribution, and histological variables (when available). The histopathological variables tabulated were type and grade of tumor which were done initially according to the WHO grading of tumors (2007), but it was updated later to the WHO 2021 CNS tumor classification system. RESULTS Out of an initial 3,108 cases identified, 114 were excluded (duplicate records, metastatic lesions, or patients under 18), resulting in a final sample of 2,994 adult PBT cases. Among these: 51.2% were male and 48.8% were female Gliomas were the most frequent group (44.9%), followed by meningiomas (19.2%) and sellar region tumors (16.7%) The most common histologic subtype was glioblastoma, isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH)-wildtype (WHO Grade 4), with an incidence of 1.39/100,000 person-years. A color-coded regional map [ Figure 2 Figure 3 Figure 2: Incidence of primary brain tumor by region (bar chart). Figure 3: Tumor type distribution. Table 1 Table 1: The annual average, median age at diagnosis, age adjusted incidence rates per 100.000 population for the major histologic groupings, and selected common histologic subtypes of primary brain tumors. The age-adjusted average annual incidence rate (2009– 2010) of newly diagnosed PBTs in Syria was 7.48/100,000 person-years. The incidence was slightly higher in males (3.83/100,000) compared to females (3.65/100,000), with a male-to-female ratio of 1.04:1 (51.16% males vs. 48.83% females). In our cohort, the most common tumor groups were adult-type diffuse gliomas, meningiomas, and sellar region tumors. The median age at diagnosis across all PBTs was 52 years, with a median age of 56 years for neuroepithelial tumors and 48 years for meningiomas. Gliomas and other neuroepithelial tumors were approximately 1.3 times more common in males, whereas meningiomas were approximately 1.6 times more frequent in females. Cranial nerve tumors and sellar region tumors showed near-equal distribution between genders. The annual incidence rates for the major histologic groupings were 3.36/100,000 for gliomas and other neuroepithelial tumors, 1.43 for meningiomas, and 1.25 for sellar region tumors [ Figure 3 Figure 4 Figure 4: Average annual incidence rate per 100.000 person/year in glioma and other neuroepithelial tumors. IDH: Isocitrate dehydrogenase, NOS: Not otherwise specified. Meningiomas represented the second most common group, with an incidence of 1.43/100,000, including grade 1 meningiomas (1.01/100,000) and higher-grade atypical/anaplastic meningiomas (0.42/100,000). Sellar region tumors were the third most common group, with an annual incidence of 1.25/100,000, including pituitary neuroendocrine tumors at 0.89 and craniopharyngiomas at 0.36/100,000. In terms of tumor behavior, non-malignant tumors constituted 57.7% of cases, whereas malignant tumors represented 42.3% [ Figure 6 Figure 6: Distribution of primary brain tumors by behavior. Age group analysis revealed that the highest incidence rates occurred in the 40–50 years’ age group, followed by the 30– 40 and 50–60 years’ groups [ Figure 7 Figure 7: Age and Sex distribution of primary brain tumors according to age-groups. Geographic variation in the incidence was moderate, with average annual rates ranging from 5.59 to 8.45/100,000 person-years across different Syrian districts [ Figure 2 Finally, the study found that 67% of all brain tumor diagnoses were made in central hospitals located in Damascus (AlAssad University Hospital, Al-Mouwasat University Hospital, Al-Mujtahid Hospital, and Tishreen Hospital), with the remaining 33% diagnosed across governmental hospitals and private centers in Aleppo, Homs, Lattakia, Hama, Deir ezZor, Daraa, Sweida, and other regions. DISCUSSION This study represents, to the best of our knowledge, the first national-level epidemiological survey of adult PBTs conducted in Syria and one of the few similar investigations in the region. It establishes a vital pre-conflict baseline for future comparison and provides a reference point for epidemiologic trends across neighboring Middle Eastern countries. Publishing brain tumor epidemiologic studies from developing regions may enhance our understanding of this heterogeneous group of diseases and shed light on risk factors influenced by lifestyle, environmental exposures, infections, occupational hazards, and genetic predispositions. Nevertheless, it is important to recognize that, for the majority of brain tumors, the underlying etiology remains unknown and likely multifactorial.[ 2 3 9 24 29 34 40 When comparing our results with major studies conducted in developed countries, notable differences emerge. According to Bondy et al et al et al et al 4 6 11 16 18 26 28 31 32 33 34 Two important articles about brain tumors epidemiology in the United States, the first one from Fisher et al 14 et al 26 Fisher et al 14 5 10 14 17 20 36 37 40 Ostrom et al 26 27 et al 1 12 23 26 27 38 39 7 8 13 15 19 21 25 29 30 33 35 Comparative analysis with the recently published National Brain Tumor Registry of China (2023) reveals similarities and differences. In both Syria and China, meningiomas and gliomas are the leading histologic types. However, the overall incidence reported in China remains higher, likely reflecting differences in healthcare infrastructure and reporting practices.[ 41 The median age at diagnosis in our study (52 years) was notably younger than that reported in Western series (e.g., 59 years in Ostrom QT et al 26 27 Finally, the main limitation of this study is the lack of previous national epidemiological data for Syria, preventing temporal or regional trend analysis. Nonetheless, the strength of this research lies in its comprehensive, prospective design, and its provision of crucial baseline data for future comparisons within Syria and internationally. CONCLUSION Our study suggests that the epidemiology of adult PBTs in Syria is characterized by a relatively low incidence rate, younger median age at diagnosis, and a tumor distribution pattern like that seen internationally, dominated by gliomas, meningiomas, and tumors of the sellar region. Differences observed compared to Western populations – such as lower glioblastoma rates and earlier median age at diagnosis – highlight the need for ongoing surveillance and improved diagnostic reporting. This study provides a valuable foundation for future research and healthcare planning in Syria and similar regions.
